definition: Li Dazhao (1889-1927), early Chinese Marxist and founding member of the communist party
plum
surname Li
big/huge/large/major/great/wide/deep/older (than)/oldest/eldest/greatly/very much/(dialect) father/father's elder or younger brother
see 大夫[dai4 fu5]
to encourage/to cut/to strain

sentences.english: Meanwhile, Li Dazhao said that today is most precious.
sentences.chinese: 同时，李大钊说过，当下是最宝贵的。

sentences.english: Li Dazhao is renowned for his varieties of legal thoughts.
sentences.chinese: 李大钊具有丰富的法律思想。

sentences.english: Li da-zhao's thought of mutual-aid evolution can be differentiated two phases.
sentences.chinese: 李大钊的互助进化思想可区分为前后两个阶段。

sentences.english: Li Dazhao was a pioneer of the Chinese revolution.
sentences.chinese: 李大钊是中国革命的前驱。

sentences.english: Li Dazhao s legal thoughts is closely connected with the legal transformation in modern China.
sentences.chinese: 李大钊的法制思想与中国近代的法制变革息息相关。

sentences.english: Li Dazhao's ideology of library science has a rich connotation.
sentences.chinese: 李大钊图书馆学思想内容涵盖丰富。

sentences.english: Li Dazhao went through the important phase of the legal system modernization of China.
sentences.chinese: 李大钊的一生经历了中国法制现代化的主要阶段。

sentences.english: In 1920 Li Dazhao met comintern Russian agent G. N. Voitrngsky.
sentences.chinese: 在苏联担任中共驻共产国际代表时的李大钊。

sentences.english: Lidazhao lived in the main room, north on the east wing after his marriage.
sentences.chinese: 李大钊结婚后就住在东厢房北面的正房。

sentences.english: Li Da-zhao is the pioneer of studying French learning thought.
sentences.chinese: 李大钊是五四时期研究法国学术思想的先驱。

sentences.english: Li Dazhao was a pioneer of the Chinese revolution.
sentences.chinese: 李大钊是中国革命的先驱。

sentences.english: Li Dazhao organized and personally directed the demonstration.
sentences.chinese: 李大钊组织并亲自指挥了这次游行。

definition: Chen Duxiu (1879-1942), co-founder of the Chinese Communist Party in 1921

Qu Qiubai (1899-1935), politician, Soviet expert of the Chinese communists at time of Soviet influence, publisher and Russian translator, captured and executed by Guomindang at the time of the Long March
Wu Yuzhang (1878-1966), writer, educator and communist politician
Cai Yuanpei (1868-1940), liberal educationalist, studied in Germany, president of Peking University 1917-19, minister of education for Guomindang
Zhang Shizhao (1881-1973), revolutionary journalist in Shanghai, then established writer
Shao Piaoping (1884-1926), pioneer of journalism and founder of newspaper Beijing Press 京報|京报, executed in 1926 by warlord Zhang Zuolin 張作霖|张作霖
Zhang Tailei (1898-1927), founding member of Chinese communist party
Song Jiaoren (1882-1913), politician of the revolutionary party involved in the 1911 Xinhai revolution, murdered in Shanghai in 1913
Chen Tianhua (1875-1905), anti-Qing revolutionary from Hunan, drowned himself in Japan in 1905
Liu Shaoqi (1898-1969), Chinese communist leader, a martyr of the Cultural Revolution
Tan Sitong (1865-1898), Qing writer and politician, one of the Six Gentlemen Martyrs 戊戌六君子 of the unsuccessful reform movement of 1898
Zhang Wentian (1900-1976), CCP party leader and theorist
Hu Shi (1891-1962), original proponent of writing in colloquial Chinese 白話文|白话文[bai2 hua4 wen2]
Li Gongpu (-1946), communist killed by Guomindang in Kunming in 1946
Liang Shuming (1893-1988), modern philosopher and teacher in the neo-Confucian tradition
Zhou Enlai (1898-1976), Chinese communist leader, prime minister 1949-1976
